data.title: Implemented layer offsets for tiled maps
data.body: Tests included. See #4047

data.title: Add TextureArrayAtlas to eliminate need for draw order management
data.body:
**Problem:** With large multi-page atlases, it takes a lot of care to sort texture atlas source images and in-game sprites in a way that minimizes batch flushes.

**Solution:** TextureArrays make it possible for multiple pages of an atlas to be used in a single draw call, binding only one texture. Within a couple of years, a large percentage of devices will support OpenGL ES 3.0, so this is a viable solution.

**Edit: Revised code significantly. See comments below**

This PR is an alternative to #4465.

data.title: BitmapFont won't read in GWT with gdx 1.9.5
data.body:
#### Issue details

I've struggled to get BitmapFonts to read and load with GWT.  I believe it may be an issue with libgdx, as I've read a few different articles and gdx forum posts to the right approach for instantiating and rendering ```BitmapFont``` objects in GDX and tried many different variations on the recommendations.  I apologize if this is either a known issue or not the recommended usage.  Thank you for the great library.

#### Reproduction steps/code
* Run latest (as of issue date) gdxsetup.jar (GDX 1.9.5) with default settings with desktop/html selected.
* In ```MyGdxGame```, add a field for a ```BitmapFont font``` and add the following to the ```create``` method:

```java
                Gdx.app.setLogLevel(Application.LOG_DEBUG);
                Gdx.app.debug("Test", Gdx.files.internal("arial-15.fnt").readString());
                font = new BitmapFont(
                        Gdx.files.internal("arial-15.fnt"),
                        Gdx.files.internal("arial-15.png"), false, true)
```

* Copy the arial-15.fnt and arial-15.png files out of the gdx lib into the assets folder.
* Set a working directory to run from the assets folder, see the ```DesktopLauncher.main``` and see that it executes correctly, showing the font rendered and the contents of arial-15.fnt displayed in the console.

![screenshot from 2016-12-14 13-23-21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/672163/21195129/83737af2-c200-11e6-9523-20c71cc5a191.png)

* run ```gradlew html:dist```, used python SimpleHTTPServer to serve from the ```html/build/dist``` directory
* get a caught exception about inability to read the ```BitmapFont```.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies

GDX 1.9.5 with all defaults versions set from the gdxsetup.jar.  I've tried with Java 1.7 and 1.8, both oracle and openjdk on windows 7, centos, and ubuntu.  Results copied were with OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_31-b13) and centos.

#### Stacktrace
You get the following caught exception, though the web server log indicates the font files served up and the log content showing the file *.fnt contents were successfully read.

![screenshot from 2016-12-14 13-16-21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/672163/21194907/b0b55e96-c1ff-11e6-911b-0b77d10c4b62.png)

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [ ] Android
- [ ] iOS (robovm)
- [ ] iOS (MOE)
- [X] HTML/GWT
- [X] Windows
- [X] Linux
- [ ] MacOS

data.title: [Feature Request]  ability to getNativeFontSize from a Bitmap font
data.body:
If I create a font from a file like thus;
```

fonttexture = new Texture(Gdx.files.internal("data/fonttest.png"), true);
font= new BitmapFont(Gdx.files.internal("data/fonttest.fnt"), 
                     new TextureRegion(fonttexture ), true);
```

It would be useful if there was a way to retrieve its native size. That is, the actual pixel size of the font the png uses.
The font class provides all manor of methods to get various font aspects (CapHeight, Decent,Ascent etc). But I cant find any that return the font size itself, and calculating font size from the other aspects is confusing at best.
To be clear as I can the information is in the *.fnt file right at the start;
eg.
`...info face="Calibri Light" size=32 bold=0 italic=0 charset=""...
`
Its that "32" I am after.
It would be nice if there was a simple  font.getNativeSize(), or similar to retrieve it. I think this should be relatively simple to add.

One current workaround is to retrieve the lineHeight upon font loading. The lineheight seems to match the fontsize by default - but as it can be changed I need to populate a hashmap on loading associating the initial values with their fonts. Then use that hasmap when I need to get the native font size.
It works, but feels very hack-ish so it would be nice if at somepoint libgdx had a more direct method.

Thanks,

data.title: setCursorPosition not working properly on OSX
Right To Left Alignment
Update JSON formatting to RFC 4627 Standards
data.body: The minimal JSON formatting is concise, but it has been confusing new Scene2D UI users who are trying to debug their code and wonder if 300+ errors in their JSON structure might have anything to do with it.

data.title: ClassCastException in Animation.getKeyFrames()
data.body:
#### Issue details
Affected calss com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Animation

code:
`Animation<TextureRegion> animation = new Animation<TextureRegion>(...);`
`TextureRegion[] f = animation.getKeyFrames();`
cause:
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" java.lang.ClassCastException: [Ljava.lang.Object; cannot be cast to [Lcom.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureRegion;

this code:
`Object[] f = animation.getKeyFrames();`
does not throw exceptions

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
LibGDX v1.9.5

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [ ] Android
- [ ] iOS (robovm)
- [ ] iOS (MOE)
- [ ] HTML/GWT
- [x] Windows
- [x] Linux
- [x] MacOS

data.title: Fix BitmapFont parsing
data.body:
#### Issue details
A recent commit https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/7420bd0f5111b73e2f1b9c5393640adfbc4aadbb changed a few regular expressions on the BMFont parser, which are now giving problems on GWT.

Desktop jvm expects to match the whole string when matching the expression to find the "id=", while GWT matches part of the string. With the current expression desktop fails to match the string (incorrectly) but gwt seems to find a match, leading to the problem when going through "id.substring(3)" when the id already contains the match group with the expected number and returns an empty string.

Desktop jvm also seems to be more forgiving when matching the expression used to find the "file=", but GWT throws an exception when it encounters "*+".

#### Reproduction steps/code
Just load a font in GWT.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.5

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [ ] Android
- [ ] iOS (robovm)
- [ ] iOS (MOE)
- [x] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] Linux
- [ ] MacOS

data.title: Custom Properties of Tiled Files. "File" And "Color" not supported
data.body:
#### Issue details

If I add a File or Color Custom Properties to my tmx file, my application crash with this Error:
`Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Wrong type given for property CustomProperties, given : file, supported : string, bool, int, float`

To reproduce, simply load a TMX files containing a Object Layer that contain Objects with custom Properties of type Color or File

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
My version of LibGDX is 1.9.4

#### Stacktrace
```
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Wrong type given for property CustomProperties, given : color, supported : string, bool, int, float
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.BaseTmxMapLoader.castProperty(BaseTmxMapLoader.java:289)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.BaseTmxMapLoader.loadProperties(BaseTmxMapLoader.java:273)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.BaseTmxMapLoader.loadObject(BaseTmxMapLoader.java:257)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.BaseTmxMapLoader.loadObjectGroup(BaseTmxMapLoader.java:120)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.TmxMapLoader.loadTilemap(TmxMapLoader.java:215)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.TmxMapLoader.load(TmxMapLoader.java:90)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.TmxMapLoader.load(TmxMapLoader.java:65)
```

data.title: Use varargs instead of lot of constructors
Fix #4471 start LWJGL3 on the first thread on Mac
data.body:
LWJGL3 needs to be started on the first thread on Mac, because
only the first thread can process input and user events.

data.title: Cannot run gdx tests with lwjgl3 on OS X
data.body:
#### Reproduction steps/code
Initialize everything needed to [run tests from source](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Running-demos-%26-tests),  
`gradle tests:gdx-tests-lwjgl:launchTestsLwjgl` should work fine.

Then run `gradle tests:gdx-tests-lwjgl3:launchTestsLwjgl3` on OS X 10.11 (or maybe any OS X), this is going to fail.

> GLFW windows may only be created on the main thread and that thread must be the first thread in the process. Please run the JVM with -XstartOnFirstThread. For offscreen rendering, make sure another window toolkit (e.g. AWT or JavaFX) is initialized before GLFW.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
adb26f3b776fca66db14d94e4a67d2ff6d9382fd and everything as referenced

#### Stacktrace
```java
:tests:gdx-tests-lwjgl3:launchTestsLwjgl3
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError
        at org.lwjgl.glfw.GLFW.glfwCreateWindow(GLFW.java:1384)
        at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl3.Lwjgl3Application.createGlfwWindow(Lwjgl3Application.java:425)
        at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl3.Lwjgl3Application.createWindow(Lwjgl3Application.java:372)
        at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl3.Lwjgl3Application.<init>(Lwjgl3Application.java:107)
        at com.badlogic.gdx.tests.lwjgl3.Lwjgl3TestStarter.main(Lwjgl3TestStarter.java:45)
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: GLFW windows may only be created on the main thread and that thread must be the first thread in the process. Please run the JVM with -XstartOnFirstThread. For offscreen rendering, make sure another window toolkit (e.g. AWT or JavaFX) is initialized before GLFW.
        at org.lwjgl.glfw.EventLoop$OffScreen.<clinit>(EventLoop.java:38)
        ... 5 more
AL lib: (EE) alc_cleanup: 1 device not closed
```

data.title: Looks like Eclipse formatting settings cannot be used in IJ IDEA anymore, a replacement is needed?
data.body:
So I tried to follow CONTRIBUTING guide.

>If you work on libGDX code, we require you to use the Eclipse formatter located in the root directory of the repository.
Failure to use the formatter will result in Nate being very upset.
If you are using IntelliJ IDEA, you can still make use of the eclipse code formatter. See this article for more information.

For some reason, importing Eclipse formatting settings doesn't work, there's just no such option, and if I pretend it's IDEA xml, then it (as expected) fails to import it.

![screen shot 2016-12-09 at 9 36 06 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1442206/21041448/b812f0aa-bdf3-11e6-9ca3-295cb23fbde5.png)
![screen shot 2016-12-09 at 9 37 01 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1442206/21041451/ba12e8b0-bdf3-11e6-90e1-ee6ce989a7f6.png)

What do I do now?

How hard is to create an alternative for IDEA? (Using Eclipse is a big turn off for me and I'm sure for many others too)

If there's a complete specification of code style in words, I can try to go ahead and create the corresponding rules for IDEA.

data.title: Use only https for fetching binaries with Ant
data.body: Trivial but important change. (Because who knows when someone will change binaries in transit in order to grow their botnet).

data.title: Removed usage of Pattern and Matcher in BitmapFont
data.body: These wouldn't function properly in GWT 2.8.0 so I changed it to simply use substring.

data.title: Crash after adding Firebase to project
data.body:
#### Issue details
My game sucessfully ran on many devices(in range from android 4.1 to 6.0). But on some of them I catch strange errors.

I already tried:
1. Upgrade to buildToolsVersion "25.0.0" (and use java 8 to run gradle build)
2. Compile project with different kotlin version
3. Disable proguard:
```
    buildTypes {
        debug {
            minifyEnabled false
            proguardFiles getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android.txt'), 'proguard-rules.txt'
        }
    }
```
4. Update/downgrade gradle

#### Reproduction steps/code
It specific error for my project. I already use multidex:
`compile 'com.android.support:multidex:1.0.1'`
```
    dexOptions {
        javaMaxHeapSize "4g" // Use gig increments depending on needs
    }
    defaultConfig {
        multiDexEnabled true
    }
```
`class AndroidLauncherApplication : MultiDexApplication()`
(yeah, I use Kotlin)
Everything seems working until I reach 64k methods limit. In fact, If I remove google play services&Firebase ads and other big dependencies my app will work well.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
libgdx 1.9.4
gradle-2.2
com.android.tools.build:gradle:1.5.0
buildToolsVersion "23.0.3"
com.google.firebase:firebase-crash:10.0.1

data.title: [WIP] implementation of texture atlas and batch which use 2D Array texture
data.body:
This is implementation of texture atlas and batch which use [2D Array texture](https://www.opengl.org/wiki/Array_Texture) instead of multiple regular 2D textures. This allows to have fewer bind and draw calls when drawing regions from huge multi-page atlases.

They require OpenGL [ES] 3+, because TextureArray requires OpenGL [ES] 3+.

Things that do not work yet:

 * Generation of mipmaps
 * Loading of [Z]KTX files into TextureArray, neither from separate files nor from single file.

Things that do work right now:

 * Creation of `TextureArrayAtlas` from regular `.atlas` files which reference PNG images. Images MUST be of same size, this can be enforced in TexturePacker config.
 * Drawing `TextureArrayAtlas.ArrayAtlasRegion` instances with `ArrayRegionBatch`.

I omitted many `draw` call overloads in batch implementation, they can be added later if needed.

I also made a simple test for this stuff which works (tested on two different OS X machines, one with Nvidia, one with AMD) but it's written in Kotlin, should I port it to Java or what do I do?

Also, there's obviously a lot of code duplication against existing libgdx code files, I didn't make any attempts to solve that yet, but when the time comes to merge this work, it should probably be done to some extent too.

Also some code comments left from original files are probably off. In that case they need to be corrected or deleted.

data.title: Improvements to barycentric methods in GeometryUtils
data.body:
I adapted this from the book Realtime Collision Detection by Christen Ericson (http://realtimecollisiondetection.net/) and this thread https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/questions/23743/whats-the-most-efficient-way-to-find-barycentric-coordinates
in theory this should work but my math might be off or even made a conceptual error. 
Furthermore, the caching might be an overkill for 99% of the use cases. And it poses the question if there should be a cached option for the 2d methods too. Finally, the bigger question is if it wouldnt be even a better idea to refactor it into a (new) Triangle class. (maybe a whole new family of Shape3D objects? there are some for bounding volumes, but for example no 3d polygon as far as I can see)

data.title: confusing try-catch in AndroidGraphics
Add license header to ShaderProgramLoader
data.body: Oops!

data.title: Aligned Particle Emitter not updating rotation on Gravity
data.body:
#### Issue details
Trying to create a "sparks" effect. I am using emitter that emits particles up with velocity that decays over time. There is also a gravity set. Thus making particles change their angle over time. Because particle is set to be "aligned" this has to also change the rotation real-time. But only initial rotation is maintained.

#### Reproduction steps/code
This issue is easy to reproduce in particle editor. just use this effect: http://pastebin.com/pq2E7xAk
Texture used in effect:
![spark-pe](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2115888/20927778/7ed25132-bbdc-11e6-909e-eef4d083203d.png)


#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.4

#### Note
While example is with usage of gravity, the issue is not related to gravity. And is happening if you just try to change angle over time. rotation is not changing over time according to movement direction.
I am unsure if it's a bug or by design.

data.title: Implements #4360
data.body:
Makes [BoundingBox](https://libgdx.badlogicgames.com/nightlies/docs/api/com/badlogic/gdx/math/collision/BoundingBox.html) compatible with 2D by performing a "*greater or equal*" comparison between `min` and `max` in BoundingBox#isValid().

Naturally, this would cause a BoundingBox with an area of 0 to be considered valid, so a `&& !dim.isZero()` was added to the expression as well in order to prevent that.

EDIT: updated the dim size check

data.title: BitmapFonts don't load properly in GWT 2.8.0
data.body:
Please ensure you have given all the following requested information in your report.

#### Issue details
Simply loading in any bitmapfont causes this same error.
Also I tried printing out the contents of the font file and its all there so it isn't an issue of the file not being loaded.
EDIT: I'm not completely sure on this but it looks like it could be an issue with the Pattern class not working in gwt and this is why it isn't parsing the font file correctly

#### Reproduction steps/code
Just load any bitmapfont (even the default arial font gives the same error)
`BitmapFont font = new BitmapFont();`
#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.5-SNAPSHOT
#### Stacktrace
//Error message
GwtApplication: exception: Error loading font file: font.fnt
Error loading font file: font.fnt
Invalid page id:
For input string: ""

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [ ] Android
- [ ] iOS (robovm)
- [ ] iOS (MOE)
- [x] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] Linux
- [ ] MacOS
